context: [1] Tumor necrosis factor Î± (TNF-Î±) exerts its effect by two distinct signaling pathways.  [2] It can trigger cytotoxicity in sensitive target cells.  [3] TNF-Î± can also promote nuclear factor ÎºB (NF-ÎºB) activity and regulate the expression of genes that interfere with apoptosis and thus conferring resistance to several apoptotic stimuli.  [4] We have observed that interferon-Î³ (IFN-Î³) sensitizes human ovarian carcinoma cell lines to TNF-Î±-mediated apoptosis and further, IFN-Î³ induces the expression of the inducible nitric-oxide synthase (iNOS) and the generation of nitric oxide (NO).  [5] This study examines the role of NO in the sensitization of the ovarian carcinoma cell line AD10 to TNF-Î±-mediated cytotoxicity.  [6] Treatment of AD10 cells with the NOS inhibitor l-NMA blocked the IFN-Î³-dependent sensitization whereas NO donors (S-nitroso-N-acetylpenicillamine) sensitized these cells to TNF-Î± cytotoxicity.  [7] Analysis of the activation status of NF-ÎºB upon treatment with NO donors confirmed the inhibitory role of NO on both the NF-ÎºB DNA-binding property and its activation.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, nitric oxide (NO) is implicated in the sensitization of ovarian carcinoma cells to TNF-α-mediated apoptosis. The study shows that NO, generated through the expression of inducible nitric-oxide synthase (iNOS) induced by interferon-γ (IFN-γ), enhances the cytotoxic effects of TNF-α. Furthermore, NO donors were found to sensitize the cancer cells to TNF-α, while inhibiting nitric oxide synthase blocked this sensitization, indicating a direct role of NO in modulating apoptotic pathways in response to TNF-α signaling.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 5 reflects a strong relevance between nitric oxide and apoptosis, as the context provides clear evidence of NO's role in enhancing TNF-α-mediated apoptosis in ovarian carcinoma cells, supported by experimental data showing the effects of NO donors and inhibitors.
